title: brexit deal theresa may cabinet meeting
story: The PM spent nearly three hours laying out her strategy to the rest of the Cabinet after rumours ministers were prepared to quit.And she served up bacon, sausage and egg sandwiches to the warring team - in a jokey reference to the pizza party eight ministers hosted last night.Mrs May told the Cabinet: Im convinced thatwe as a Government stand together and stand firm we can achieve this.A No spokesman insisted no ministers threatened to resign in protest against the PMs Brexit plans.But Mrs May is still fighting off a rebellion from her DUP allies - as they threaten to block her domestic agendashe doesnt accept their demands on Brexit.Tomorrow the PM will travel to Brussels where she will make the case for her Chequers plan in front of other EU leaders.Today senior Eurocrats Michel Barnier and Donald Tusk both said a deal is unlikely to be struck this week and called on the UK side to break the deadlock.Mr Barnier said: We must find a solution to ensure that there is no hard border in any circumstance on the island of Ireland. We are not there yet.Several subjects remain open, including Ireland. We need more time to find this global agreement and achieve the decisive progress we need to finalise this negotiation on Britains orderly withdrawal.We will take this time, calmly and seriously, to find this global agreement in the next weeks.And Mr Tusk added: Unfortunately, the report on the state of negotiations that I got from Michel Barnier today, as well as yesterdays debate in the House of Commons, give me no grounds for optimism before tomorrows European Council summit on Brexit.As I see it, the only grounds for hope for a deal for now is the goodwill and determination on both sides. However, for a breakthrough to take place we need more than goodwill, we need new facts.Tomorrow I am going to ask Prime Minister Mayshe has concrete proposals on how to break the impasse. Only such proposals can determinea breakthrough is possible.Last night, a group of eight senior ministers met over spicy meat pizza to air their frustration about the PM.The ministers who gathered in Andrea Leadsoms office included Michael Gove, Jeremy Hunt, Dominic Raab and Liz Truss.They reportedly agreed they should continue backing Mrs May as she battles to fight off Brussels attempts to carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Penny Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary who attended the meeting, said today: No one is planning on resigning. We are all doing our jobs and we are trying to get the best deal for this country, and thats it.Labour MP Virendra Sharma, a backer of the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign, mocked the ministers for failing to launch a challenge to the PM.He said: After days of briefing about their plot we expected these Brexiteers to give the Prime Minister a pizza their mind. It seems like they folded quicker than a calzone.And Tory backbenchers have denied they want to force Mrs May out of office.Steve Baker, the Brexiteers shop steward, admitted: “There really isn’t time for a long leadership contest. And there aren’t the Eurosceptic numbers to change Prime Minister.”But Mrs May could face a tougher challenge from the DUP, which is propping up her majority in Parliament.Nigel Dodds, the partys leader in Westminster, said thatshe tries to put a border in the Irish Sea the DUP will say: How can we continue implement your domestic agenda, your budgets and everything  He added: Under the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act there are a lot of things that we can not support in terms of the government’s domestic and financial and welfare agenda which does not trigger the possibility of Jeremy Corbyn coming into No.”This week European leaders warned that No Deal is closer than ever after talks between officials broke down on Sunday night.But Mrs Mays ministers have insisted that eventhere isnt a Brexit deal this week, one could be struck at a special summit next month.THERESA May must ramp up No Deal preparations or risk Brexit talks resulting in total chaos, ex-Tory leader William Hague warned today.The respected peer called on the PM to start building lorry parks and drawing up customs forms so that Britain is ready for disruption at our borders.Lord Hague also said Mrs May should consider ripping up the blueprint for Brexit negotiations - and consider signing up to the European Economic Area for the next three years.He warned the Tories are at breaking point as MPs row over whether or not to back the PM as she heads to Brussels for talks with European leaders.The former Foreign Secretary said: It is now essential to turn up to full throttle the preparations for leaving without a deal.Yes, that sadly means everything from printing customs forms to building lorry parks in Kent.A No Deal Brexit is extremely undesirable, and might be prevented by Parliament, but since it could happen it has to be prepared for psychologically and politically, not just logistically.He added that fresh thinking - which could include adopting an EEA solution to give the Government more time to negotiate a deal - could help Mrs May shore up her position.

title: photo gran chinese ghost girls v a museum
story: Jane Cunningham was snapping pictures of her family in East London and didn’t see anything amiss.But when she got back and looked at the day’s iPhone pictures she noticed two small Chinese girls in the background, apparently peering out of a window.The spooky photograph shows the two small women looking towards the camera, with one half-submerged in the wall - even though the room they were in was empty.And now Ms Cunningham is convinced she has caught spirits from the other side on film.The -year-old said of her trip to the museum in Bethnal Green, East London: “I did not expect to see these spirits at all. It was really crazy.“My daughter asked me to take some photographs of her and it was not until several hours later that we realised these strange people were in the photograph.“It was a really rainy day and there was no one outdoors. These two oriental women are very tiny and clearly dressed in outfits from another era.“You cannot see the one inside the wall and can just see her face, but the one that was in frills, was half in and half out the building.“It was very out of place as everyone had anoraks on and hoods because it was a rainy day.“That is what fascinated me so much.”Alongside the two female ghosts, Ms Cunningham also saw a purple orb in the shape of a skull on another picture.She added: “The skull above was really quite frightening because it showed that maybe the girls had been tortured or maybe had lived in a horrible situation back then during the th century - they had to work day and night, doing such intricate work.”The phantoms were located in the west wing of the building, in the area designated for the storage of visitors’ prams and buggies.The room is completely plain and there are no pictures on the walls or displays whatsoever.Ms Cunningham, of Stockwell, South London, added: “The building was chocka that day, so we had to take our pram around with us, so there was simply no room for humans to be in that room.“It was crazy because the whole area was chock-a-block with prams, and it was a grey and miserable day so it’s just incredible that someone would be looking through the window like that - half-in and half-out.”The sight of the spectral visitors inspired Ms Cunningham to conduct research into the area and the museum in particular.She said: “Because I am spiritual, I was motivated to undertake research to find out more about these girls. These girls were spirits and they were trying to come through.“I did a bit of research and found out that during the th century the building was owned by the gentry but they couldn’t afford to complete its decoration.“It essentially became a women’s prison then - housing women to finish off the decoration and building.“So I presume these women were part of that society in that prison from the orient and they were trying to come through to me and show me they were there.”Ms Cunningham admits to being a spiritual person who has seen phantoms and ghosts of family members since the age of , including her grandmother.She said: “My house now has a seven-year-old little girl who wasn’t going anywhere until I identied her.“I didn’t know her and could not recognise her, so she was just a nuisance really. It was not until my boyfriend recognised her that she went.”She hasn’t ed to the museum yet, but is “excited to visit to check out the area again.”She called both the VA Museum of Childhood and the VA Museum but has not heard back.The museum was founded in  as the Bethnal Green Museum and now houses the largest collection of childhood objects in the UK.The museum has been approached for comment.

title: new photos sunken british tanks d day
story: The war tanks sunk during Operation Smash - a huge training exercise held on a Dorset beach in April , just weeks ahead of the Normandy landings.Six lives were lost during the drill - but a lesson was learnt so that, on D-Day, British and Canadian tanks were launched in shallow water.Nick Reed from The Isle of Purbeck Sub Aqua Club, which has launched a project to map the history of the seven sunken tanks, said the six soldiers lost did not die in vain.Everybody says that Operation Smash was an absolute, complete disaster, said Nick.Well,  tanks were launched and seven sank, so that means  got to shore in this exercise and from that the British learnt a lesson.So when the British and Canadians launched their tanks on D-Day, they didnt launch theirs offshore because it was too rough.Whereas the Americans launched theirs five kilometres offshore.The result of the American decision is well-known - just two of the  tanks initially deployed to storm Omaha beach made it ashore.Omaha would be the bloodiest of the D-Day beaches.If we hadnt got armoured support ashore on D-Day, our troops may not have established a beach head, said Mr Reed.So in many ways the sacrice of those six guys may have changed the course of World War Two - thats the way we like to think of it.Their sacrice wasnt in vain, things were learnt from it and maybe that contributed to the success of D-Day.Conditions at the e site off Studland Beach are notoriously changeable, making the sunken tanks a challenge to photograph.The new images of them are thought to be the clearest ever taken.Paul Pettitt, who photographed the wrecks with his we Alison, said: Its rough as you like.Those pictures were done over the course of a whole summer. Some days we went down and werent able to get anything.The worst problem is the wind direction which kicks up the silt and sand on the bottom, and makes it go very gloomy down there.But we got a lucky break one day when we got some really clear visibility and were able to get these pictures.The tanks have also taken on new lives as articial reefs.Theyre absolutely full of wildle, said Mr Reed.There are several big conger eels living in one of the main tanks, theres crabs, theres lobsters, theres big shoals of fish that swim around them.Thats almost like a commemoration of the men themselves - men died on these tanks but these tanks now are providing le to the marine animals around the area.The Duplex Drive Valentine tanks were equipped with a buoyant canvas screen which could be raised up around the tank and sat above the water line.But soon after the tanks were launched the wind changed and water started to sweep over the top of the screens.They were launched in suitable conditions but the wind blew up just after they were launched, said Mr Reed.The skirts, which provided the buoyancy, were only about a metre above the water - and obviously what keeps water out will keep water in.So I think most of them were swamped and sank.Earlier this year, a man believed to be the last-surviving soldier from Operation Smash - who is also a crew member from one of the doomed tanks - was located.Albert Price, , is now living in the West Midlands.Its hoped hell be able to attend a  year commemoration of Operation Smash next year.

title: terrified mum posts 50 an hour job ad for someone to take her kids trick or treating on halloween
story: The single mother, who suffers from severe social anxiety, is offering £-an-hour to look after her three young children.She said that she gets “very scared at Halloween because of the costumes and speaking to strangers to ask for sweets for the kids.”She posted the ad on on Childcare, a site connecting parents with nannies, tutors and babysitters with more than . million users nationwide.Her post, which was submitted last week, is a last resort as she has been unable to find anyone  to treat her kids.But the mum won’t let that stop her three children, aged nine, seven and three, having a great time.The ad calls for a professional to help the children into their costumes and lead them trick or treating from pm to pm on October .The founder of Childchare, Richard Conway, said: “When I saw this advert put onto the website, I wanted to help the woman instantly.“She’s clearly trying to do the best for her children and is more than happy to pay someone to perform this service.“I got in touch with her to ask how I could help, and promoting this advert seemed like the best way I could help her.”

title: young entrepreneur kicked out of school fixes oaps fences for free
story: Caring Jon Horne set up his own fencing business at the age of  after getting kicked out of school four years earlier.The -year-old decided to help OAPs for free after witnessing them getting ripped off by rogue traders.He also continually came across war veterans who admitted they had to choose between food and heating and getting basic home repairs done.Jon set up JD Property Services in Birmingham at the age of  and felt compelled to help the older generation after seeing some charged several times what they should be for simple jobs.And his out-of-the-ordinary acts of kindness have now seen him gain attention online, with his original Facebook post gathering almost , messages of support and a further , messages sent to him directly. It has also been shared , times.Jon was disgusted recently when he met a WWII veteran who was quoted three times more than he should have been for a job, and he even had to stop his own grandmother from being scammed.With this in mind Jon came up with the idea of helping his older customers over the winter period after fixing an elderly woman’s fence for free over the weekend because she was struggling to keep on top of her bills.He said: “Yesterday I had a call from an elderly lady who had three fence  blow down in the bad weather.“I went out to take a look within an hour as she was quite distressed and worried about the security at her home.“I repaired the fence for her same day and when asking how much she owed me, I decided nothing.“She was reluctant to let me walk away without a payment but after a short conversation with her, she explained how she struggled to keep on top of her bills but the fence repair was a must.“I cant believe some of the older generation are in a situation where they have to decide whether to be warm or in this case have a secure fence.“Due to this, throughout the bad weather we are offering FREE fence repairs to any senior citizens who are struggling.”The team now have their first four lucky OAP customers booked in for free repairs on Monday.Because of the sudden surge in demand and influx of requests, Jon has set up a Crowdfunder. You can donate yourself here.

title: john bercow calls for commission to investigate mp harassment
story: It comes a day after High Court judge Dame Laura Cox delivered a damning report that found that a culture of "deference, subservience, acquiescence and silence" had allowed bullying and harassment of staff to thrive.Her inquiry painted a picture of a workplace where MPs enjoyed "God-like status", knowing they would never be subject to disciplinary action and where abusive behaviour was covered up.Complaints ranged from staff being shouted and sworn at and belittled on an "almost daily" basis to the "predatory" behaviour of some male MPs towards female staff.

title: saudi consuls home to be searched for khashoggi clues
story: US secretary of state Mike Pompeo arrived in Riyadh this morning to hold talks about the case with Saudi King Salman.Overnight, Turkish forensic teams searched the consulate building where renowned journalist Mr Khashoggi was last seen entering.Until Monday, Riyadh had not allowed Turkish investigators to search the consulate, with reports that both sides were at odds over the conditions.The investigators, who eventually searched the premises for eight hours, took samples with them, including soil from the consulate garden, according to an official at the scene.Forensic vehicles also took away a metal door from the garden."The Turkish crime scene investigators carried out searches in the consulate and took the things deemed necessary," a senior Turkish official said, acknowledging the dficulty of collecting evidence  days after the alleged incident.Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says the investigation in the Saudi consulate is looking into toxic materials.Mr Erdogan added that he hoped a reasonable view would be reached as soon as possible in the investigation.A search of the Saudi consuls personal residence in Istanbul is due to get under way today.Mr Pompeo was greeted by the king at the royal palace, and thanked the king "for accepting my visit on behalf of PresidentTrump" before going into a closed-door meeting.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: tories making major universal credit
story: NewsUniversal Credit set for major climbdown by the Tories reveals leaked documentIt comes after Tory Esther McVey confirmed she will migrate no more than , existing claimants on to the benefit until mid-ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMore than , people have signed the Mirrors petition to halt the rollout "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe government is planning a major climbdown over Universal Credit, a leaked document has revealed. It comes hours after Tory welfare chief Esther McVey confirmed she will migrate no more than , existing claimants on to the benefit until mid-. Her confession suggests the vast majority of the UKs .million existing benefit claimants will not begin so-called managed migration until then. Now the BBC reports this move will extend UCs estimated finish date from March  to December , the ninth delay to the rollout. And a document leaked to the Corporation also reveals a string of measures to offer people more help. Hard-up families could now get higher transition payments and lower loan repayments after UC drove desperate people to rent arrears, food banks and prostitution. But crucially, there is NO mention of a halt to the rollout or any change to the taper rate - a core problem with the hated policy.  Instead, according to the document obtained by the BBC, government officials plan to:Continue paying income support, ESA and jobseekers allowance for two weeks after someone makes a UC claim Reduce deductions when some is paying back an advance loan from % to % of monthly benefit Give more help to the self-employed after warnings the policy will crush themThe changes would reportedly cost hundreds of millions of pounds . But an extract from the document also warns the changes might not even be possible. We can currently offer no assurance that ultimately these proposals will prove to be deliverable, can survive legal challenges where they can be delivered, and do not invite new political criticism by generating new policy issues, it says, according to the BBC.  Critics are likely to say the measures - which have emerged a year after a separate pound.bn package of tweaks - are not enough. There is no commitment to halt the rollout, and no mention in the BBCs report of the taper rate. Universal Credit is handed over in one payment, which tapers away by p for every extra pound people earn above pound a month. Critics have complained that this is too steep and leaves families worse off. Citizens Advice chief executive Gillian Guy said the leaked measures could reduce” hardship. But she warned: “These measures alone will not solve all of the problems. The government must make changes to ensure no one is left without enough to get by.”  Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said: “The Government must stop the roll out of Universal Credit immediately. We need urgent answers from Esther McVey about whats going on and what action the Government will take to tackle the many flaws in the system. Paul Noblet of the charity Centrepoint said: “Having tested the system, the government is finally learning it still has a long way to go before it fulfils its aim of supporting those who need help the most.” Department for Work and Pensionssources did not deny the end date - estimated as March  by the National Audit Office just months ago - could become December , saying only it would be in . A DWP source insisted the managed migration of .million claimants would still begin in July .  But they conceded the phasing of that migration was open to change - and a spokesman confirmed the department would work with a maximum of , people in the first year. Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, who last week admitted some UC claimants will be worse off, has repeatedly said she was looking at further changes to the system. Yesterday she told MPs: Under the process of managed migration, the roll-out will be slow and measured. It will start not in January , but later in the year. For a further year we will be learning as we go with a small amount of people - maybe , - to ensure that the system is right. More than , people have signed the Mirrors petition to halt the rollout. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. A DWP spokeswoman confirmed: “We have long said that we will take a slow and measured approach to managed migration. This will not begin in January , but later in the year, after a period of preparation. For a further year we will then begin migration working with a maximum of , people, continuing with our ‘test and learn’ approach. This is to ensure the system is working well for claimants and to make any necessary adaptions as we go.” The spokeswoman added: “We will publish full plans for the next stage of Universal Credit rollout, including managed migration, in due course. Anything before that point is speculation and we do not comment on leaks.

title: tory mp craig mackinay overspent
story: NewsTory MP Craig Mackinay overspent on election campaign in bid to end Nigel Farages parliamentary ambitions foreverSouth Thanet MP Craig Mackinlay denied two charges of making a  election expenses declaration in Southwark crown courtShareByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT NewsCraig Mackinlay arriving at court with his we, Kati "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory MP Craig Mackinlay overspent on his  general election campaign in a bid to end Nigel Farages Parliamentary ambitions forever, a court heard today. The South Thanet MP, , along with his election agent Nathan Gray, , and party activist Marion Little, , are alleged to have been complicit in submitting  expenditure declarations following his victory on May . Southwark Crown Court heard the Conservative Party put extra resources into the campaign to win the Kent seat because prior to the EU referendum Ukips support was on the rise. Nigel Farage indicated he would step down as Ukip leaderhe failed to win South Thanet so it was clear this was not going to be any ordinary election campaign, prosecutor Aftab Jafferjee QC told jurors. He said it became a two-horse race won by Mackinlay with a majority of around , in an electorate of ,, which Gray later described in an email to Little as a truly magnicent election campaign.  Spending limits apply equally to every prospective Parliamentary candidate of every political hue across the UK and those limits seek to ensure integrity and public confidence in the most obvious example of this countrys democratic process, namely a general election, the prosecutor continued. He said expenditure is tightly regulated over two stages - a short and a long campaign - and it is the job of a Parliamentary candidate and their election agent to ensure limits are scrupulously observed. Declarable expenses include the costs involved to get the candidate elected, such as printing of leaflets, putting up posters and staff costs, such as the employment of Gray as an election agent, Mr Jafferjee explained. In South Thanet the limit for the expenditure was just over pound,, while for the short campaign it was just over pound,. Declarations made by Mackinlay and Gray came in below the limit, at pound, and pound, respectively. But Mr Jafferjee said: It is the prosecution case that neither of these declarations as to expenditure - the longfigure of just over pound, and the shortfigure of just under pound, - were true, and by some considerable margin, though that does not matter. Each of these three defendants were complicit in advancing those  declarations. He told jurors a signature purporting to be Nathan Grays in relation to the longhad been forged. The court heard Little, along with a press officer, was sent from Conservative Campaign Headquartersto stay in the Royal Harbour Hotel in Ramsgate, arriving on March , . The prosecutor told jurors they worked to get Mackinlay elected from the moment they arrived, while Little wrote an email in which she described herself as being marooned in South Thanet. Marion Little went onto effectively manage Craig Mackinlays election campaign so that he would be elected and Nigel Farage would be defeated, he said. This was not just what is known as a marginal seat, but it was a contest which could see off Nigel Farages Parliamentary ambitions forever. The court heard Little told police she was not working for Mackinlay but carrying out national campaign work. She now claims she went to Kent to prevent the election of Ukip and the benefit to Mackinlay was collateral to that, jurors were told. But Mr Jafferjee said: While we accept she may have been doing some things nationally, she was there for one purpose. The prosecutor said Mackinlay will blame his lack of experience and unawareness of what Little and others were doing. Grays defence will similarly highlight his inexperience, stating he was marginalised by the arrival of Little, and that he has no idea how his forged signature came about, the court heard. But Mr Jafferjee said: It is the prosecution case each of these defendants involved themselves in a deliberate under-declaration and non-declaration of election expenses. Mackinlay, from Ramsgate, Kent, denies two charges of making a  election expenses declaration under the Representation of the People Act . Gray, of Hawkhurst, Kent, denies one charge of making a  election expenses declaration and a further charge of using a  instrument under the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act . Little, of Ware, Hertfordshire denies three counts of intentionally encouraging or assisting an offence under the Serious Crime Act . They are all on unconditional bail. The trial, which is expected to last until December, continues.

title: actress 22 marrying man 29
story: NewsActress, , marrying man  YEARS older than her - and shell be stepmum to his three grown-up childrenLexsy McKowen and John Avilés met on a film set and they bonded over their shared love of comic books and musicShareCommentsByRebecca Drew:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJohn and Lexsy are madly in love "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old actress is set to marry a man  years older than her - and shell become stepmum to his three grown-up kids. Lexsy McKowen met John Avileacutes, , on a television set where she was an extra and John was doing the cast’s makeup in April, last year. Metalhead John was wearing a long black leather coat that instantly caught Lexsy’s eye and sparked a conversation between them and they discovered a mutual love for comic books, horror and music. After filming, the pair would stay in the car park talking until the early hours. The pair who live together in San Diego, Calornia, USA, say the age-gap was never an issue for Lexsy as she has always been attracted to older men like Jeff Goldblum and Slash when her friends were into Justin Bieber.  However, John found the age dference dficult at first as he had never dated anyone so young and his three children from a previous relationship are all a similar age to Lexsy at ,  and . Both families were dubious of the relationship at first but have since grown to accept it. “I met him on my first set which I was wasn’t going to go to because it was in a sketchy part of the city but I went anyway. He was the makeup artist that night and I was just a featured extra,” said Lexsy. “He wears this really cool black leather long coat and so my first words to him were ‘Hey, I like your coat,’ and he, to my surprise, said thank you really sweetly. “He has this metalhead look to him and I was expecting him to be an a**hole, but he was the sweetest nerdiest guy I’d ever met. We talked comic books and metal during set and then after we had wrapped we stayed in the parking lot until am just talking about everything.  “He was an older guy so that was great for me since I’ve always liked dating older than me, but I had just got out of a three-year relationship and I told myself I won’t date for like five years. “I fought myself for a month to not fall in love again. Obviously, that didn’t work out and Im really happy I fell in love with him. “Our age gap is  years. For me, it wasn’t a problem. I had dated an older man previously and I’d always been infatuated with older men when I was younger. “Kids were crushing on Justin Bieber and Jesse McCartney and I loved Johnny Depp, Jeff Goldblum and Slash, so for me it was natural.” John said: “Well were both haunt actors and love comic books, as well as heavy metal, so those were big factors for us.  Plus, in our first encounter, we talked for something like three hours, and after that I couldnt stop thinking about her. “The age gap was a little tough for me, only because I never dated someone with this much of an age split, but I wouldnt change this for anything. “Both of our families were hesitant. I think more on my side than hers, however my mum came around to it when she saw how we interact with each other, and that she wasnt a frivolous, flighty, type of a person. “I think the most dficult thing in our relationship is that were both in the arts and that makes things really tight financially for us. I know Ive had to come a long way due to some very hard times, but we kind of work together through these things.” John and Lexsy are excitedly getting ready for their wedding at the end of the month and are looking to move to LA.  Although, marrying John means that Lexsy will technically be his children’s stepmum, this isn’t a label she wants to be known by. Lexsy hit back at people who might not agree with their age gap and said their relationship is the same as everyone ’s. “We are going to move to LA to hit the ground running on our careers in acting and makeup,” said Lexsy. “We have talked about kids and I would like to have just one kid. “Since I’m marrying him Im technically his children’s stepmum, but I just want to be called by my name and they already have a mum. I feel uncomfortable calling myself their stepmum since they are grown adults. “Our relationship is a big norm in the film industry and has been for decades. It’s not out of the ordinaryyou really think about it. “Our relationship is just like everyone ’s. The only time our relationship is dferent is on outward appearance. We don’t see each other’s ages. “We have fights, we struggle with money, we go on fun dates or stay in and watch Law and Order in our pyjamas. We are just as normal as anyone . “Rarely people askI’m his daughter but most of the time we’ve been lucky with people calling me his girlfriend or sometimes his we.”

title: bbc news presenter simon mccoy
story: NewsBBC News presenter Simon McCoy says royals back his deadpan Prince George birth coverageMcCoys rather bewildered air as he discussed Duchess of Cambridge in labour with Prince George went viral back in  - and he believes he was rightShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video simon-mccoys-deadpan-reporting-lindo-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBBC News presenter Simon McCoy has claimed the royal family think his deadpan coverage of Prince Georges birth was absolutely right:. Prince George, the first child of Prince William and Kate Middleton, was born on July ,  to huge media coverage worldwide. For days before the birth of the new heir, camera crews and journalists were camped outside the Lindo Wing of St Marys Hospital.While covering the birth from outside the hospital, McCoy memorably admitted that there was not all that much to reveal as the Duchess of Cambridge was in labour . He said: Well, plenty more to come from here of course. None of it news because that will come from Buckingham Palace. But that wont stop us. The video quickly went viral, adding some humour to the days of repetitive coverage. Speaking about the viral video, the veteran BBC newsreader said he did the right thing by reporting there was no news.Speaking to the Radio Times , McCoy said: “I do know they [the royals] were watching in the hospital when the Duchess of Cambridge was giving birth to Prince George and I was outside.Someone told me the family thought I’d got it absolutely right. They were watching and wondering what on earth was going on outside.  Nothing was happening and I said as such – and it’s much better than some of my rivals who were speculating on the level of dilation. I think once you get into that realm of commentating, you’ve lost the plot.” Last year, McCoy was equally sarcastic when reporting on the Duchess of Cambridges due date for Prince Louis. Simon read out the breaking news statement live on air - adding his own dry wit when it came to the delivery. He said: “Now, baring in mind that they announced that she was pregnant back in September and it was thought that she was around two or three months pregnant, I’m not sure how much news this really is.”  Simon then added: But anyway, its April so clear your diaries, get the time booked off cause thats what Im doing. Kate gave birth to Prince Louis on April  this year and Princess Charlotte was born on May , . Meanwhile, there is another royal baby on the way as Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are expecting their first child early next year.

title: driver staff lock themselves out
story: NewsDriver and staff lock themselves out of OWN train leaving passengers stranded on cold, wet The doors on the Great Western Railway service were reportedly proving to be an obstacle and the incident has been described as "shambolic"ShareCommentsByAlex RichardsSports writerDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video shambles-driver-guard-locked-out-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A driver and staff accidentally locked themselves out of their own train - leaving fuming passengers stranded on a cold and wet railway , according to reports.The incident involved a .pm Newton Abbot to Truro service on Sunday, one of the few which had not been cancelled because of Storm Callum. Its driver and a station manager were filmed trying to pull open one of the doors, before the manager was reportedly forced to clamber into a window and manually release the door locks. The incident has been described as shambolic. When passengers arrived at Newton Abbot train station on rail replacement buses they found the doors were proving to be an obstacle for Great Western Railway, Cornwall Live reports.In true British fashion the large crowd of passengers for Plymouth and Cornwall queued, quietly baffled and increasingly frustrated, for more than half an hour on the , it is reported. Despite staff wrestling with the doors, they failed to budge, reports said. A  worker was heard remarking I have never heard a crowd cheer for train doors opening before.  And, in a bizarre addition, travelers reportedly noted that a loudspeaker announcement kept repeating that the inaccessible .pm service at the  had been cancelled. The loudspeaker would then inform the passengers that their next train would be the .pm service at the , reports said. Falmouth man John Dudding, , described explained how door-gate was just one in a string of incidents during his journey to Falmouth from Cardf. I walked up towards carriage A and had a clear view of the engine, and saw that the driver kept peering his head out of his window. There were noises asthere were attempts to unlock all the doors. A younger guard struggled with opening the door. The video I took was only the second go at opening it. He had to climb through a window to access some button which eventually worked.  He added: That wasnt the end of it though because we were told the train manager had not arrived. We eventually just left without any sort of announcement. It was a bit shambolic. You understand that sometimes organisations are thrown into unexpected situations, and the coach transport was set up well, but the communication just seemed to get worse as we got further into Cornwall. He claims no one informed travellers that all routes beyond Truro were by bus, because of maintenance around Newbury. He says his journey began at .pm and ended at around .pm.and Cornwall Live has approached GWR for comment.

title: farmer built huge berlin wall
story: NewsFarmer built huge Berlin Wall of hay bales when denied planning permission - which fell over and destroyed cemeteryFrancis Courtenay, , erected the ft hay mountain after being repeatedly refused planning permissionShareCommentsByTom Bevan:,  OCT NewsThe tower of hay bales built by a farmer in Barnstaple, Devon "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn angry farmer who was denied planning permission built a massive tower of straw bales in protest - which fell over and destroyed graves in a cemetery next door. Francis Courtenay, , put up the ft hay mountain after his application for three new homes on his land was refused on the grounds they would have been an eyesore. He decided to stack bales on top of each other higher than the proposed homes to make a point. But his protest backfired spectacularly when several bales flew off the top as Storm Callum hit. They broke several gravestones and crushed flowers left at the neighbouring churchyard.  The wreckage at the Grade II listed St Thomas A Beckett church in Newton Tracey near Barnstaple, Devon, has left many in the village furious. Francis - who has owned the land since  - has now apologised to the vicar for what he said was an accident and promised to put it right. But he has vowed to leave the bales up until he gets planning permission. He said: The bales were put higher than the houses would have been and I just wanted to make a point. We had a bit of a disaster though and there was a terric gale, which moved three bales. It blew off the top ones but I will put everything right and sincerely apologised to the vicar. He said he understands that accidents happen. I understand now that the wall was too high. I will make the graves right and I have apologised unreservedly to the vicar for that. It was a monumental cock up and I am sorry for that. But Mr Courtenay remains unrepentant about the wall itself and has vowed to leave it there for the near future. He added: It got stopped by just one woman from Historic England complaining that it may have a visual effect on the church. I told the village what I was going to do. The vast majority of local people, including the vicar, church and the parish council, have been very supportive.  That field is a prime development site and there is no reason to refuse planning there. I can understand that people may be upset about it, but its not there to upset the locals. Its only upset the awkward ones anyway. I will leave it there until Historic England sorts the matter out. Mr Courtenay said the objections on visual grounds were ridiculous and that he built the wall to show them a visual disturbance. He said: They said thehouses would cause a visual effect on the church, which is a joke. I told them You think its a visual effect  Ill give you a visual effect. Residents in Newton Tracey have been left fuming by Mr Courtenays hay bale tower. Chris Moore said he believes the bales were erected to spite the villagers who objected to the planning application. He said: Some people in the village said it would spoil the beautul views, so he moved the bails in front of the church to block their view of the countryside. It is a very high wall, five bales high in places. It is very unstable and could be dangerous. Everyone in the parish is fuming, because they believe he did it to spite them. It could have been really dangerous, imaginethere had been someone there when the bales blew off. The bales that broke the graves have been moved now, but the broken headstones and squashed flowers are still there. Its all so unnecessary.  Historic England said it had raised objections as the principle of development will result in harm to the signicance of the grade II listed church. North Devon District Council subsequently rejected the initial plans due to a lack of affordable housing provision and an increase in traffic. The decision notice also states that the proximity to the listed church and its open, rural and undeveloped setting would be to the signicant detriment of the church. It is also believed that the site may be of medieval and Roman archaeological signicance.

title: john lewis shopper discovers unintentionally
story: NewsJohn Lewis shopper discovers unintentionally rude card that reads "f*** you" due to unfortunate font useAndrew Hawkes was attempting to find the perfect gt wrap for his girlfriend when he discovered this amusing mistakeShareCommentsByJoe Pagnelli:,  OCT NewsJosefine Blunk, , from Berlin, was shocked when she saw the gt tag with a rather rude message "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA John Lewis shopper looking for gt wrap for his girlfriends birthday was stunned when he spotted a gt tag that appeared to read f**k you. Andrew Hawkes was browsing the shelves at the high-end department store to find the perfect gt tag for Josefine Blunk and did a double-take when he spotted the pink and gold label. At first glance Andrew, , believed the pound. Hotchpotch tag read f*k you due to the typeface style and the combination of upper and lower case letters. However on closer inspection the label, which he spotted in the Trafford Centre branch of the store in Trafford, Greater Manchester, last month reads for you. Andrew from Manchester said: I had to do a double take when I first saw it. I was so confused as I didnt see for you at all.  I thought maybe it was a practical joke, it just looked completely out of place. When I got back I showed it to my other half and she read it as f**k you as well. Its strange because they capitalised the R so its an interesting design that made it confusing to read. When is Spring   For all those trying to work out when the next royal baby will arrive, the specic dates of when Spring falls is also complicated. There are actually two dferent dates for when Spring begins - Meteorological or Astronomical - so it depends on which system you use. To complicate it further, the seasons are not always the sameso the start and end dates can fall on a dferent times each year. Meteorological Spring looks at the seasons by weather are based on temperature cycles as well as the calendar.  This year it fell on March  and ended on May , and it  fall on the same dates. title: schoolboys tragic words dad just
story: NewsSchoolboys tragic words to his dad just weeks before he died in parents armsEvery day Callum Halls parents feared the worst and when the time came he closed his eyes and peacefully left the worldShareCommentsByLisa HutchinsonReporter:,  OCT NewsCallumwith younger brother Liam and dog Jack "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolboy with cancer told his father “I want to get better” weeks before taking his final breath and dying in his parents arms.Callum Hall, , was diagnosed with leukaemia two years ago, and despite undergoing chemotherapy and having bone marrow transplants, nothing could be done to stop the disease spreading.Devoted parents Pete and Michelle were told to take him back to their home in Newcastle and make memories.But on Friday, October  Callum closed his eyes for the last time and died in his parents arms, reports Chronicle Live .The youngster had been in agony and confined to his bed in his final days, but he managed to muster the strength to tell his mother how much he loved her.  “The last words he said to me was ‘mam, I love you,’ Michelle said. I also took his dog Jack up to see him, I put him on his bed and he said his goodbyes - they were inseparable. “On Thursday I asked himhe was in pain and he squeezed my finger and his morphine was increased. Then on Friday we were changing his pyjamas, we were both holding him and Pete said ‘he’s going’. Callum took a few breaths and he went in our arms. We both hugged him, we were just crying, both of us in tears.”  Callums funeral is being held today and Newcastle United footballer Paul Dummett will be joining mourners after becoming friends with Callum during his illness. It was two years ago when Callum had a routine test for a blood disorder he shares with his mother that it revealed the entirely unconnected disease - acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. It was then Magpies-mad Callum struck up a friendship with Dummett after a friend of Pete’s said he had known the left back from being a kid. And after Dummett heard of Callum’s plight, he popped round to his house with a signed shirt and stayed for two hours playing FIFA games on the Playstation. From that moment their friendship grew as they spent hours on numerous occasions playing Playstation - ending with a FIFA draw between the pair.  “They became good friends, Paul would come to ours and play FIFA with Callum for a couple of hours at a time. He’s a really nice bloke and he’s coming to Callum’s funeral,” said Pete. After Callum was diagnosed, the Gosforth Junior High Academy pupil went through chemotherapy and a donor match was made for a bone marrow transplant. Callum, who has seven-year-old brother Liam, spent seven weeks in a sterile bubble at Newcastle Royal Victoria Infirmary and started to get better. He went back to school in September  and was building up his hours but became unwell again. Season ticket holder Callum underwent more tests and in January  the family’s worst nightmare was confirmed when doctors said a rare situation had occurred and a dferent kind of leukaemia - acute myeloid leukaemia - had taken over.  “As far as we were concerned he was cured. He was slowing getting back to school and started to get back to his football at Kingston Park Football Club Under s,” said Pete. But mother’s intuition kicked in and Callum’s illness set alarm bells ringing with Michelle. She said: “I just knew something was wrong, he was showing symptoms like before, he was pale and was tired and going straight to bed when he came in from school. I had the feeling it had come back but I never thought it would be a dferent kind of leukaemia. “We were toldhe had another bone marrow transplant, he would have a % survival rate, but we were willing to take the chance. Another donor was found but Callum’s chemo didn’t work and the leukaemia spread.  They said it was pointless to have another transplant and we were told nothing  could work. We were told to take him home and make memories.” Pete, who works at Tesco, added: “We told Callum the donor wasn’t ready, we didn’t want him to have nightmares. But I think he knew, he didn’t want to worry us. We were protecting him and he was protecting us.” Callum, who was given a Braveheart Award last year, began to get weaker and became really poorly in September and was confined to bed. Pete, , said: “It was just the week before he got really sick when Callum said ‘Dad, I want to get better,’ but we knew that wasn’t possible. “It’s heartbreaking really, we knew it was going to happen, we knew it was coming but we didn’t know when. Each day we thought was he going to go in his sleep  But he was here for seven months when they only gave him two weeks to a month to live. He was so strong.  “Liam was staying at his auntie Jacqui’s when Callum passed. It’s ashe knew and waited.” Liam is missing his big brother and is taking the responsibility of looking after Callum’s mischievous miniature Jack Russell. And in Callum’s coffin a photo of him with his brother and trusted pet is lying by his side, along with other pictures and messages. Parents and coaches from Kingston Park Football Club will also attend the funeral as they join family friends and NUFC’s Paul Dummett. “Callum is wearing his Newcastle United black and white strip, he was Newcastle mad, and we are playing Local Hero. He just loved his football,” added Michelle.

And a substantial amount of snow is threatening Scotland, northern and central England. Conditions could be even more extreme than during the Beast from the East earlier this year. story: NewsDoctor removes  PUBIC LICE from girls eye after her eyelash became infectedThe six-year-old schoolgirl had been complaining that her left eye was constantly itchyShareCommentsByScott Feng:,  OCT NewsPubic lice are not normally found in an eyelash "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A doctor in China has removed  pubic crab lice from a little girls eye after she ed from holiday with the parasites infesting her eyelashes.The six-year-old from the city of Suzhou in East Chinas Jiangsu province was taken to the Childrens Hospital of Soochow University complaining that her left eye constantly itches. Ophthalmologist Zhao Lei took one look at the girls eye under a microscope and immediately diagnosed her with a pubic liceinfection. The tiny ectoparasite, also known as a crab louse, lives on coarse human hair and feeds on blood.  Doctor Zhao spent  minutes plucking  lice and  eggs from the girls eyelashes after she refused to allow her pretty lashes to be cut off, reports said. Footage from the hospital shows the lice still crawling around after being removed from the girls eyelashes. The crab-like parasites are thought to have been contracted during a recent holiday overseas. Doctor Zhao said he has already treated two pubic louse cases this month. Average Irish person has been sexually exposed to .m people - the population of Puerto RicoThe parasites can latch onto humans by living on clothing and bed linen, and can live anywhere on the human body where there is coarse hair, such as the pubic region, armpits or eyelashes. Zhao recommended regular bathing, changing clothes, and washing bed linen. It is unclear how exactly she became infected with the lice.

title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have been applied to his dad’s old team.”The fans also pointed out should the Killie player who ed to win the kick, Jordan Jones, be handed a two-game ban, that in itself could damage Dundee.The games he would miss would be against St Mirren and Hamilton, the two sides immediately above the Dark Blues at the foot of the Premiership.SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell was copied in when the letter was e-mailed and has promised a response will be given.

title: major traffic disruption on key dundee road to last another four weeks
story: Dundee motorists are set to face major traffic disruption on the A for the next four weeks.The project got under way on Sunday and is involving surfacing works across three locations between Claypotts junction and Elliot roundabout at Arbroath.Eddie Ross, operating company representative for BEAR Scotland, said the work was “essential to ensure the continued safe use of this stretch of the A”.Project bosses have tried to ensure there will be minimum disruption to road users with work taking place overnight between pm-am, Sunday-Friday.No work will take place on Friday and Saturday nights.During the operation sections of the A will be closed overnight with traffic erted locally.The majority of the project will take place using a mph convoy system to keep road users as well as motorists safe. Any ersions will be signed in advance.Bus services will follow ersion routes, with stops within the closure area unavailable during those periods.Phase one started between Upper Victoria and Ardestie interchange at Woodhill westbound, and Ardestie interchange bridge.Work being carried out by Tayside Contracts will mean traffic being erted south from Upper Victoria Interchange on to the C Carnoustie Road, the A Barry Bypass to the B Newbigging Road, the B Drumsturdy Road to C Ethiebeaton to West Grange Roundabout and on to the A.On Sunday and Tuesday nights works will start with the on-slip closure from pm, and a mph convoy working on the dual carriageway.On Monday and Wednesday nights the slip road will be re-opened, however a mph convoy system will remain in place.During the closures traffic will be erted to the B Newbigging Road, the B Drumsturdy Road to C Ethiebeaton, the West Grange Roundabout and on to the A.BEAR Scotland will be supervising work being carried out.Mr Ross said: “We will do everything possible to keep disruption to a minimum and have planned the project to take place overnight as well as avoiding the busier Friday and Saturday nights.”

title: teles ninewells parking petition gets huge backing as 1500 call to freeze the fees
story: More than , of you have got behind the Tele’s campaign to freeze car parking charges at Ninewells Hospital.In just seven days, more than , readers have signed our petition which asks Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd to keep its car parking charges at existing levels until at least November next year. vw, px"  Scotland’s Health Secretary Jeane Freeman has also said she would like to abolish the charges.We launched our campaign following the announcement that parking fees at the hospital are to rise next month.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd is locked in a -year contract with the health board to run all the car parks at Ninewells.Fees have risen over the years, meaning people who are attending the hospital through necessity are having to fork out more and more.The firm plans to raise the costs again, so day tickets and permits for staff will go up next month.Ms Freeman said: “I would like to be able to abolish car park charges at Ninewells – just as we have done in other hospitals across Scotland – but this is one of three car parks which are locked into long-term contracts that previous governments signed up to.“We have previously raised concerns about moves to increase these charges and called on the company involved to reconsider.“Charging to park at a hospital puts an unnecessary financial burden on families and those needing treatment.“In the funding packages we use for new health projects, we have made sure that charging for hospital car parking is prohibited.“We expect health boards to work to ensure that any charges in place are kept to a minimum and I expect all contracts to be kept under review to ensure best value for the public purse.”Among those who took the time to sign the petition was Elizabeth Malone, from Lochee.Mrs Malone said: “I think it’s disgraceful that they are putting the car parking charges up again.“It’s not right that nurses and doctors and visitors to patients should have to keep paying increased charges for parking their car.”Janette Doig, of Dunholm Road, said: “I signed the petition because I think it is very unfair that charges are to rise again.”David Irons, from Menzieshill, said: “I signed it for two reasons. It’s not fair that people have to pay to park at Ninewells when they don’t have to at other hospitals all over Scotland.“Also, we find it very dficult to park outside our own home because of hospital parking.“If people going to the hospital didn’t have to pay it would ease the parking situation for local residents.”You can support our campaign by signing our petition, which asks Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd to keep its car park charges at existing levels until at least November next year.PETITION: Sign to support the Tele#s campaign to Freeze the Fees at Ninewells Hospital" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp tele-calls-for-freeze-on-parking-fees-at-ninewells-hospital embed # secretiOgVgGLEXJ" data-secret"iOgVgGLEXJ" width"" "" title"#PETITION: Sign to support the Tele#s campaign to Freeze the Fees at Ninewells Hospital# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"
